course_title: Special Topics in History: American Violence
class_notes: This seminar investigates the meaning and historical significance of violence in American history from the pre-colonial era to the present day. Scholars from a variety of historical subfields have utilized violence as an analytical lens and framework for groundbreaking research. This course will investigate cutting-edge scholarship in Native American, African American, Asian American, and Latinx history, as well as histories of labor, capitalism, and diplomacy. Readings will intersect with a variety of historical and interdisciplinary themes including gender and sexuality, trauma, memory, and religion. The syllabus reflects a recent surge in histories of American violence, and course readings offer fresh insights for students with a diverse range of research interests. The goal of this course is to prepare students for comprehensive examinations, graduate-level research, and teaching by exposing them to a broad range of historical themes, interpretations, and methodologies.
